page.title: 03PUBLIC HOUSES.
page.content: {The Dog and Partridge. Originally built as a farm house in 1642 and converted in the nineteenth century, this clean oak-beamed pub has a very "Olde Worlde" feeling. Large stables and a coach yard provide evidence of the building's coach-house past. There's nothing ultra-modern or artificially antique about this quiet country pub's comfortably old-fashioned atmosphere. This is an ideal place to stop for lunch after a walk or drive. Bar meals are served in front of a large open fire between twelve and one thirty. Typical meals are meat pie potatoes and vegetables, steak sandwiches, salads and scampi. A wide range of spirits and beers are available, a pint of beer costs around a pound, a single measure of spirits costs around eighty pence.
